captions.text:
You ever had one of those relatives that don&#39;t 
know you very well but you had one conversation

with 10 years ago in which you briefly mentioned 
sort of liking Lord of the Rings, so every fucking

Christmas since, they&#39;ve gotten you a Lord of 
the Rings box set of some kind? I worry something

like that has happened with me and triple-A open 
world games. I worry they overheard me mentioning

that I enjoyed Assassin&#39;s Creed 2 16 years ago 
and now they think that&#39;s all I fucking want:

stealth action games with crafting and 
collectibles. Except every now and again,

this relative gives me a bag of dog food and 
gently soiled wet wipes instead of Lord of the

Rings, which in this analogy is Suicide Squad: 
Kill the Justice League. Considering that it

was in my review of Ghost of Tsushima that I first 
coined the term Jiminy Cockthroat as a convenient,

short way of saying &quot;stealth action open 
world with crafting and collectibles,&quot;

I wasn&#39;t holding out too much hope for 
Ghost of Yōtei changing that trend much,

and it absolutely bloody well doesn&#39;t, but 
at least it&#39;s a new remaster of the Lord

of the Rings with a new John Rhys-Davies 
interview and certainly shines in contrast

to Assassin&#39;s Creed Shadows, which was a 
bag of particularly downmarket dog food.

The comparison is going to be inevitable because 
it&#39;s one for one the exact same plot of Assassin&#39;s

Creed Shadows, right down to it opening with the 
protagonist weeping over her murdered family while

a bunch of dudes in masks stand silently in a line 
nearby, trying to wordlessly prompt each other

to apologize. The chief difference being that 
this is literally the very first thing you see,

where in Assbleed Badows, it took about 
three hours of flapping about to get there.

This all sets the tone for Yōtei being 
a much more straightforward experience,

aiming more for pulpy Samurai Western revenge 
plot, dropping out all the confused stuff with

the second protagonist and obligation to bring 
&quot;real history&quot; to life so all the inevitable

melodrama hits like a custard pie into the face 
of a respectable historical documentarian. No,

it&#39;s just your name&#39;s Atsu; six powerful masked 
gits killed your whole family; kill all of them.

Having now spent your entire teens learning 
the usual suite of Jiminy Cockthroat abilities:

fighting, throwing grappling hooks at contextual 
prompts, and the mysterious ability to become

intangible while touching vegetation so 
it doesn&#39;t move when you crouch in it.

On the outset, Yōtei&#39;s strength as an open world 
is its focus on immersion. It&#39;s set up so you more

stumble upon things than set objective markers 
and mindlessly beeline towards them like Amy

Winehouse noticing an unopened Bacardi Breezer, 
giving you a chance to appreciate the game&#39;s look

without vomiting random icons all over the screen 
like Amy Winehouse after eating a smartphone. So,

I&#39;m happily riding around the scenery, thinking, 
&quot;Blimey, how many fucking cherry blossoms does

one particle engine need?&quot; when suddenly, BAM, 
ambushed by Ronin. Stab them all up; last one

surrenders; gives you a lead on who would be most 
optimal to stab next; the adventure continues.

Naturally, Ghost of Tsushima&#39;s characteristic 
feature where the wind blows in the direction

of your objective has returned and is still as 
atmospheric and immersive as it ever was, and

it&#39;s still annoying that to trigger it, you have 
to finger the trackpad on the controller in the

manner of a clumsy virginal prom date in the back 
of his rented limo trying to bring off his laptop.

There&#39;s a few other no doubt company-mandated 
controller gimmicks. There&#39;s a little campfire

minigame where you have to squeeze the triggers to 
blow on the sparks and use the Sixaxis to wave a

fish on a stick, and it&#39;s all very pathetic and 
the game loses nothing if you skip it. &quot;Now we

can say the PS5 offers the quintessential Ghost 
of Yōtei experience!&quot; Sony must have said. And

apparently, that involves being mildly annoyed 
with a trackpad covered in snot. But I&#39;d say the

defining moment of Ghost of Yōtei came at around 
the midpoint of my play time when, after I very

cinematically rode my horse across another 
bloody cherry blossom field and paused atop

a hill to see the rolling landscape that would be 
the setting of the next chapter unfold before me,

the sunrise behind the distant mountains 
framing the scene with perfect cinematography,

and I said to myself, &quot;Wow. I am so bored.&quot; Hello 
ennui, my old friend. Because every chapter of

the game&#39;s narrative was going through the 
same routine: go to the inn for this area,

get ambushed, find the wise weapon master for 
this area, learn the new weapon, get ambushed,

go after your target, try to ambush them, get 
double-backsy reverse ambushed &#39;cause it&#39;s too

early to resolve the plot and token support NPC 
for this area hasn&#39;t finished their story arc yet.

Hold that thought; let&#39;s briefly weigh in on how 
the combat feels. It feels like you&#39;re playing

a drum kit in the middle of a merry-go-round. 
Because every enemy just blocks all your hits

until you break their guard with heavy attacks 
or perfect parry, and to perfect parry reliably,

you can either learn all the timings and carefully 
watch their movements or you can just keep tapping

the block button like it&#39;s the hi-hat, and 
that netted more or less identical results.

Lose concentration for a moment and a dude will 
rush in and just chomp all your health away with

a three-stab combo, so it hardly matters how 
many times you&#39;ve bathed in a hot spring to

increase max health by an inch unless you&#39;re 
really invested in looking at someone&#39;s bottom,

and thinking about it, you are currently browsing 
the internet, so I guess never mind. In short,

direct combat is annoying. Thankfully, you can 
stealth around some of it. And as in Tsushima,

you have the option to drop stealth and 
call out the enemy for a duel if you have

sinned and wish to punish yourself. 
But it seems out of character for

Atsu to do that &#39;cause she&#39;s a mercenary 
assassin and as far as she&#39;s concerned,

unblemished honor and a McChicken Spicy 
is worth one mediocre dining experience.

It&#39;s the tiresome predictability of the plot 
and its occasional loud, embarrassing public

disagreements with the interactive format that 
ultimately soured me. Guess it&#39;s spoiler time.

Warning! The eensy weensy spoiler will be 
descending the water spout for the remainder

of this video. There&#39;s a bit where you infiltrate 
a palace and you&#39;re directly above the unwitting

main villain and the &quot;Assassinate&quot; prompt appears 
over their head, and I rolled my eyes knowing it

was far too early for this to take, and indeed 
at some point between the rafters and the ground,

Atsu is replaced by her incompetent twin sister 
Cutscene Atsu—Catsune?—who proceeds to completely

fuck everything up, stabbing the floor one foot 
to the left, and so the plot must roll on for

another tedious handful of hours. Oh, and later 
on we&#39;re introduced to a character&#39;s daughter,

who is spunky and precocious and the age Atsu 
was when her family were killed, and immediately

I knew with an unvibrating certainty I can&#39;t 
explain that Atsu was gonna be raising this

kid by the end. And sure enough, I was right, 
but only because the kid&#39;s dad dies in the most

infuriatingly pointless manner imaginable. We&#39;re 
mid-final boss fight and basically got the guy on

the ropes when kid&#39;s dad pops up, saying, &quot;Hey! 
Just making sure you&#39;re motivated enough!&quot; Well,

I&#39;m currently literally killing the guy, so 
I&#39;d say so, dude. &quot;Eh! Could always have more!&quot;

*Gets stabbed.* Fucking Cutscene Atsu strikes 
again. &quot;Yahtzee, it&#39;s pronounced cutscen-eh.&quot;
